user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ObjectIdFindByName:
```c
int32 OS_ObjectIdFindByName(osal_objtype_t idtype, const char *name, osal_id_t *object_id)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /*
     * As this is an internal-only function, calling it with NULL is allowed.
     * This is required by the file/dir/socket API since these DO allow multiple
     * instances of the same name.
     */
    ARGCHECK(name, OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND);
    LENGTHCHECK(name, OS_MAX_API_NAME, OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, idtype, name, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        *object_id = token.obj_id;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ObjectIdFindByName:
#define ARGCHECK(cond, errcode) if(!(cond)){returnerrcode;}
...
#define LENGTHCHECK(str, len, errcode) ARGCHECK(memchr(str,'\0',len),errcode)
...
#define OS_MAX_API_NAME 20
...
#define OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND (-17)
...
#define OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG (-13)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, const char *name, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(lock_mode, idtype, OS_ObjectNameMatch, (void *)name, token);
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_objtype_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I scanned the provided function and related definitions for any compiler-specific language extensions (for example: __attribute__, __asm__/asm, __extension__, typeof/__typeof__, GNU statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, labels-as-values, Microsoft-specific keywords, or other documented compiler extensions). None of those appear in the target code. The constructs present are standard C (function definitions, macros, typedefs, casts, memchr usage, forward struct typedef). The custom integer/type names (int32, uint32, osal_id_t, osal_objtype_t) are project typedefs and not compiler extensions; their definitions should be checked only if they themselves use compiler-specific features, but no such evidence is present in the shown code. The ARGCHECK macro text as shown contains a spacing anomaly (returnerrcode) which appears to be a formatting/typo issue rather than a language extension. For these reasons there are no code fragments that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (language extensions).
